abstract: A back-of-the envelope calculation shows that the parts of the once-storied computing conglomerate could be worth just under $26 a share – 85 percent more than the company’s current share price.
snippet: A back-of-the envelope calculation shows that the parts of the once-storied computing conglomerate could be worth just under $26 a share – 85 percent more than the company’s current share price.
lead_paragraph: David Packard and William Hewlett may be Silicon Valley’s answer to Romulus and Remus in Rome’s founding story, but the era of their brainchild, Hewlett-Packard, as an everything-to-everyone conglomerate is coming to an end. Its chief executive, Meg Whitman, and its board, not to mention investors, won’t stick around for an arduous and risky five-year turnaround project. Breaking the company into good bits and selling bad ones must be on the agenda for 2013.

headline.main: Why Breaking Up H.P. Makes Sense

byline.original: By Rob Cox and Robert Cyran
